data.title: Alice Lee (Roosevelt) Longworth (1884-1980)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? data.text:
Alice Lee Longworth formerly Roosevelt

Born 12 Feb 1884 in New York, United States

Ancestors

Wife of Nicholas Longworth III — married 17 Feb 1906 in The White House, Washington

Descendants

Mother of Paulina (Longworth) Sturm

Died 20 Feb 1980 at age 96 in Washington City, District Of Columbia, District of Columbia, United States

Profile last modified 2 May 2024 | Created 31 Dec 2008

This page has been accessed 23,836 times.

This person is a descendant of a US President/Vice President

Join: US Presidents Project

Discuss: Presidents

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Birth

1.2 Marriage

1.3 Affair

1.4 Death

1.5 Burial

1.6 Children

2 Sources

Biography

Alice Lee Roosevelt, daughter of President Theodore Roosevelt, was born on 12 February 1884, in Manhattan, New York County, New York to Theodore Roosevelt and Alice Hathaway Lee. She married Nicholas Longworth III on 17 February 1906, in Washington, District of Columbia. They were the parents of at least 1 daughter. She lived in Oyster Bay, Oyster Bay, Nassau, New York in 1910 and Cincinnati, Hamilton, Ohio for about 10 years. She died on 20 February 1980, in Washington, District of Columbia, at the age of 96, and was buried in Rock Creek Cemetery, Washington, District of Columbia.

After her mother's death on Feb. 14th and her father leaving for North Dakota to get over his loss, Alice was cared for by her aunt, Theodore's sister, Anna Roosevelt, known as "Barnie", for two years, until her father remarried.[1]

Birth

Alice Lee Roosevelt was born on February 12, 1884, in New York City, New York, to Alice Hathaway Lee and Theodore Roosevelt.[2][3][4]

Marriage

Many gentlemen wanted to court Alice but she selected an older gentleman, Nicholas Longworth III (a member of US Congress House of Representatives 1903 - 1931 from Ohio). They were married on 17 February 1906 in Washington, D.C.[5][6][3][7][8][9][10]

Affair

During her marriage, Alice carried on numerous affairs.

It was general knowledge in D.C. that she had a long, ongoing affair with Senator William Borah. When Alice's diaries were opened to historical research they indicated that Borah was the father of her daughter, Paulina Longworth.[3]

Death

On Feb. 20, 1980, she died in her Embassy Row house in Washington DC of emphysema, pneumonia, and cardiac arrest. She outlived her half-siblings at the age of 96.[11][12][3][13][14][15]

Burial

Alice is buried in Rock Creek Cemetery in Washington, District of Columbia.[16][3]

Children

Alice and Nicholas had one child: [3]

Paulina Longworth, b. Feb. 14, 1925, d. Jan. 27, 1957.

Sources

↑ Biography at Theodore Roosevelt Center
